oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Lorrie Morgan Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Lorrie Morgan (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Lorrie Morgan; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Lorrie Morgan says 'Probably good place to start' -- (00:03) Morgan address the fact that Leave the Light On is her first LP, recorded by RCA -- (00:33) Biff Collie introduces "Trainwreck of Emotion" and Morgan reflects on her desire to find up-tempo tracks when she was shown "Trainwreck of Emotion" by Jon Vezner and Alan Rhody -- (02:08) Morgan discusses the relationship of Vezner and Kathy Mattea -- (03:02) Morgan's first number one record "Out of Your Shoes" is described by Morgan as a twist to a tale never sung before -- (04:01) Morgan does into depth about "Out of Your Shoes" being about friends borrowing from each other -- (04:26) Collie asks about the album order and Morgan attests to not knowing how her song order was chosen -- (05:24) Collie and Morgan discuss "I'll Take the Memories," referring to the slow ballad as a projection of Morgan's idea of divorce -- (06:25) Morgan reveals how "I'll Take the Memories" has changed in her mind -- (06:38) Collie and Morgan discuss Morgan's late husband and the idea of songs being reflections of her late husband -- (07:32) Morgan recalls doing a demo of "Far Side of the Bed" while working at Acuff Rose and Collie and Morgan discuss the process of a demo track -- (09:00) Morgan discusses her father's (George Morgan) influence on establishing herself in Nashville while Morgan fought her 'father's-daughter' image -- (10:24) Collie recaps the Music City Album Review and introduces Morgan to introduce "Dear Me" -- (10:34) Morgan describes when she worked at Acuff Rose, and her recording "Dear Me" for Carson Whitsett and Buzz Aldrich -- (11:31) Morgan tells of how each record label prior had over looked "Dear Me" -- (12:33) Morgan gives her advice to new members of the music business -- (13:13) Morgan reflects on "Dear Me," "Far Side of the Bed," and "Leave the Light On" and their ability to resonate with consumers -- (14:15) Morgan touches on constructive criticism and recalls her being known as hard to work with -- (16:02) Morgan has difficulty describing "Five Minutes" and eventually Morgan discusses the difference in styling from a typical Morgan song -- (18:50) Morgan says "He Talks to Me" is her favorite and Morgan discusses her love of Mike Reid -- (19:37) Morgan reflects on Keith Whitley's influence on "He Talks to Me" -- (21:03) Morgan and Collie discuss how Whitley would communicate with Morgan almost daily -- (22:03) Morgan discusses the past artists who recorded "It's Too Late (To Love Me Now)" and reflects on her disconnect from its message -- (23:00) Morgan reaffirms how there is not a story behind why it was recorded -- (24:04) Collie and Morgan discuss the music industries influence on Morgan's children (Morgan and Jessie) -- (26:38) "Gonna Leave the Light On" is said to be a song that Morgan initially disliked, but recorded on behalf of Barry Beckett -- (29:01) Morgan and Collie reflect on Morgan's father's wishes and how she is the only singer of five siblings, but her brother Marty's talent in music is underappreciated -- (30:31) Morgan tells about her sister Candy not enjoying singing and Morgan and Collie reflect on her sisters name -- (31:05) Collie and Morgan discuss how Morgan had recently switched management and Morgan reflects on her excitement for the future -- (32:08) Collie and Morgan joke about Morgan's disc jockey career -- (32:27) Morgan expresses the end of the album (32:32) Morgan says her goodbye
